required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy, Safety and Tolerability of a Novel Malathion Formulation in Patients 2 Years and Older With Head Lice
clinical_study.official_title: A Multi-Center Phase III Study to Evaluate Ovide Lotion 0.5% Formulation, for the Control of Head Lice in Pediatric Subjects and Adult Subjects With Pediculosis Capitis

brief_summary.textblock: In this study, Malathion Gel 0.5% will be compared to Nix (permethrin 1%) as a treatment for head lice in patients 2 years of age and older. Malathion Gel 0.5% is a new formulation of an established head lice treatment. The new formulation has been evaluated in 2 previous studies of patients 2 years of age and older.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a Phase III, multi-center, investigator-blinded, two-arm, randomized, parallel group study, evaluating the safety and efficacy of a Malathion Gel, 0.5% formulation, manufactured by Taro. The objective is to show superiority of the novel product to an active control, Nix® Crème Rinse, manufactured by Insight Pharmaceuticals.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Index Subjects Free of Any of Lice 14 Days After Their Last Treatment.
primary_outcome.description: Treatment Success was evaluated using the Efficacy Intention to Treat (eITT) (LOCF) Efficacy ITT (eITT) was considered definitive. The primary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were considered a Treatment Success 14 days after their last treatment (Day 14 visit if only treated on Day 1, Day 21 visit if treated on Day 1 and Day 7). Index subject: 95 from 254 randomized (the youngest subject in the household who met index case criteria( having nits and at least 3 live lice))

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Index Subjects Lice-free 2 Weeks After Their Last Treatment
primary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Efficacy Intention to Treat (eITT) (No LOCF) The primary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were considered a Treatment Success 14 days after their last treatment (Day 14 visit if only treated on Day 1, Day 21 visit if treated on Day 1 and Day 7).

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Index Subjects Lice-free 14 Days After Their Last Treatment
primary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Per Protocol Population (PPP) The PPP included all subjects who complied strictly with the protocol and had outcome data for all required visits. Superiority analysis in the PPP was considered to be supportive.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of All Randomized Subjects Who Were Treated and Returned for at Least One Post-treatment Visit.(LOCF)
primary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Modified Intention to Treat (Modified ITT) (LOCF) The Modified ITT included all randomized subjects who were treated and returned for at least one post-treatment visit. Subjects with missing efficacy data were included first with LOCF and then with non-LOCF

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of All Randomized Subjects Who Were Treated and Returned for at Least One Post-treatment Visit (Non-LOCF).
primary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Modified ITT (non-LOCF) The Modified ITT included all randomized subjects who were treated and returned for at least one post-treatment visit. Subjects with missing efficacy data were included first with LOCF and then with non-LOCF

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Subjects Who Were Considered Treatment Success 14 Days After Their First Treatment in the Efficacy ITT (LOCF))
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Efficacy ITT (LOCF) The secondary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were lice-free 14 days after their first treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Subjects Who Were Considered Treatment Success 14 Days After Their First Treatment in the Efficacy ITT (Non LOCF))
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Efficacy ITT (non LOCF) The secondary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were lice-free 14 days after their first treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Subjects Who Were Considered Treatment Success 14 Days After Their First Treatment in the PPP
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the PPP The secondary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were lice-free 14 days after their first treatment. The evaluations in the PPP was considered supportive.

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Subjects Who Were Considered Treatment Success 14 Days After Their First Treatment in the Modified ITT (LOCF)
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Modified ITT (LOCF) The secondary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were lice-free 14 days after their first treatment. The evaluations in the Modified ITT was considered supportive.

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Subjects Who Were Considered Treatment Success 14 Days After Their First Treatment in the Modified ITT (Non LOCF)
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Modified ITT (non LOCF) The secondary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were lice-free 14 days after their first treatment. The evaluations in the Modified ITT was considered supportive.

arm_group.description: Nix applied to scalp for 10 minutes

intervention.description: Malathion gel 0.5% applied to scalp for 30 minutes. May be repeated in 1 week if head lice are still present.
Permethrin 1% shampooed into scalp for 10 minutes. May be repeated in 1 week if head lice are still present.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Confirmed active head lice infestation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergy to pediculicides or hair care products
- Scalp conditions other than head lice
- Previous head lice treatment within the past 4 weeks
- Current antibiotic treatment

reference.citation: Meinking TL, Vicaria M, Eyerdam DH, Villar ME, Reyna S, Suarez G. A randomized, investigator-blinded, time-ranging study of the comparative efficacy of 0.5% malathion gel versus Ovide Lotion (0.5% malathion) or Nix Crème Rinse (1% permethrin) used as labeled, for the treatment of head lice. Pediatr Dermatol. 2007 Jul-Aug;24(4):405-11.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subjects were recruited at 2 dermatology clinical practices

group.title: Malathion Gel
group.description: Malathion gel 0.5% 30 minute application Malathion gel 0.5%: Malathion gel 0.5% applied to scalp for 30 minutes. May be repeated in 1 week if head lice are still present.

group.title: Nix Creme Rinse
group.description: Nix applied to scalp for 10 minutes Permethrin 1% rinse: Permethrin 1% shampooed into scalp for 10 minutes. May be repeated in 1 week if head lice are still present.

drop_withdraw_reason.title: Post treatment Assessment out of window

baseline.population: Baseline characteristics were evaluated to identify differences between treatment groups which were not eliminated by randomization.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Proportion of Index Subjects Free of Any of Lice 14 Days After Their Last Treatment.
outcome.description: Treatment Success was evaluated using the Efficacy Intention to Treat (eITT) (LOCF) Efficacy ITT (eITT) was considered definitive. The primary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were considered a Treatment Success 14 days after their last treatment (Day 14 visit if only treated on Day 1, Day 21 visit if treated on Day 1 and Day 7). Index subject: 95 from 254 randomized (the youngest subject in the household who met index case criteria( having nits and at least 3 live lice))
outcome.population: The Efficacy Intention to Treat (eITT) population was the primary population for demonstrating the superiority of the Malathion product to the active control Nix® Crème Rinse. eITT population: included all index subjects with at least one application of treatment. Proportion of Subjects that are lice-free 14 days after their last treatment

outcome.title: Proportion of Subjects Who Were Considered Treatment Success 14 Days After Their First Treatment in the Efficacy ITT (LOCF))
outcome.description: Treatment Success in the Efficacy ITT (LOCF) The secondary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were lice-free 14 days after their first treatment.
outcome.population: Treatment Success in the Efficacy ITT (LOCF). The secondary efficacy variable was the proportion of index subjects who were lice-free 14 days after their first treatment. Based on the protocol predefined imputation of missing efficacy data, the effective sample size = 82; frequency missing = 13.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
